metadata.title: The Fusiform Face Area: A Module in Human Extrastriate Cortex Specialized for Face Perception
metadata.author: Nancy Kanwisher, Josh McDermott, Marvin M. Chun
metadata.abstract: Routing models, a form of conditional computation where examples are routed through a subset of components in a larger network, have shown promising results in recent works. Surprisingly, routing models to date have lacked important properties, such as architectural diversity and large numbers of routing decisions. Both architectural diversity and routing depth can increase the representational power of a routing network. In this work, we address both of these deficiencies. We discuss the significance of architectural diversity in routing models, and explain the tradeoffs between capacity and optimization when increasing routing depth. In our experiments, we find that adding architectural diversity to routing models significantly improves performance, cutting the error rates of a strong baseline by 35% on an Omniglot setup. However, when scaling up routing depth, we find that modern routing techniques struggle with optimization. We conclude by discussing both the positive and negative results, and suggest directions for future research.

highlights: Modern neural networks process each input in the exact same way

Much of the work exploring input-dependent processing has taken the form of per-example routing within a network (Shazeer et al, 2017; Fernando et al, 2017; McGill & Perona, 2017; Rosenbaum et al, 2018), which is form of conditional computation (Bengio et al, 2013)
We show how routing models with architectural diversity represent a broad family of models that generalize a number of powerful models
By ablating the architectural diversity, we show that diversity plays a key role in achieving strong performance

In order to ensure that routing decisions play a nontrivial role in the performance of the model, we leverage the neural architecture search cell of Bender et al (2018) whose set of operations has been tuned to maximize performance while removing unnecessary operations
We found that architectural diversity can have a big impact in final performance
key_statements: Modern neural networks process each input in the exact same way

Much of the work exploring input-dependent processing has taken the form of per-example routing within a network (Shazeer et al, 2017; Fernando et al, 2017; McGill & Perona, 2017; Rosenbaum et al, 2018), which is form of conditional computation (Bengio et al, 2013)
We show how routing models with architectural diversity represent a broad family of models that generalize a number of powerful models
By ablating the architectural diversity, we show that diversity plays a key role in achieving strong performance

In order to ensure that routing decisions play a nontrivial role in the performance of the model, we leverage the neural architecture search cell of Bender et al (2018) whose set of operations has been tuned to maximize performance while removing unnecessary operations
We found that architectural diversity can have a big impact in final performance
summary: Modern neural networks process each input in the exact same way.

Much of the work exploring input-dependent processing has taken the form of per-example routing within a network (Shazeer et al, 2017; Fernando et al, 2017; McGill & Perona, 2017; Rosenbaum et al, 2018), which is form of conditional computation (Bengio et al, 2013).
Effective routing can be achieved by training another small neural network that learns to route examples through the supernetwork.
Previous works on routing use a homogeneous set of experts, where all experts share the same architecture and only differ in the parameter values (Shazeer et al, 2017; Rosenbaum et al, 2018).
We attempt to remedy this problem by introducing architectural diversity in routing models, with different experts having different architectures and parameters.

The main differences are that (a) they use experts with the same architecture, whereas we demonstrate that using diverse experts is important, and (b) they use a small routing depth while we benchmark models with large routing depth.
Diverse routing networks generalize many neural architecture search methods.
Before testing diversity and increasing routing depth, we verify that experts are able to capture dataset structure when trained with noisy top-k gating.
We benchmark routing models with architectural diversity on an Omniglot (Lake et al, 2015) multi-task learning setup.
This result suggests that the diverse routing models are effectively performing a form of architecture search.
Since it is challenging to know apriori what operations are important for a given task, using diverse architectural components simplifies modeling and improves performance in routing models.

Since it is challenging to know apriori which set of operations work well for which dataset, this result suggests that adding diversity of operations to models in addition to adding multiple copies of a single important operation type is a straightforward way of creating routing models that work well for different datasets without requiring much tuning.

In order to ensure that routing decisions play a nontrivial role in the performance of the model, we leverage the neural architecture search cell of Bender et al (2018) whose set of operations has been tuned to maximize performance while removing unnecessary operations.

This negative result demonstrates that while increasing routing depth should theoretically improve routing models, current techniques for optimizing the router, such as noisy top-k gating, are empirically unable to learn strong solutions.
We introduced diversity to routing models and experimented with increasing routing depth.
While architectural diversity will help improve routing models on large scale tasks, the routing depth optimization problem will continue to impede success.
headline: We address both of these deficiencies
